Not exactly a project, especially not in the changelog sense, but I'm actually really excited about the Go programming language.
https://gist.github.com/831856 -- example of the syntax. the Same function walks two trees in parallel coroutines, then compares them synchronously via channel communication.
kindof reminds me of c meets python meets erlang
Its like node.js, but faster and better language primitives, but without the possibility of great browser interop (which is only a subset of what node is used for anyway)
Line 33 (n.b. is it just me or is the click-line-no-to-goto-anchor behavior on gists broken in chrome? line numbers are links but don't do anything at all), the for loop, makes me sad though
That's neat, my first look at Go back when it came out left me with a negative impression but that snippet's not bad.
no range() or similar? C-style for loops are just butt ugly
There is a range.
I'm not 100% sure it works on ints, maybe just collections. *looks*
doesn't seem to operate on ints. just collections. http://golang.org/doc/go_spec.html#For_statements   see range a bit down the page.
@justinlilly Is the gist from the golang code lab?
...duh. I really shouldn't ask questions within 5 minutes of waking up.

@justinlilly With Andrew Gerrand? I did the same class (or a similar one) when he was in London last year. Recognized the code instantly. :)

psh, gh_pages
@kennethreitz :P
s/gh-pages clone/gh-pages helper/

@acdha that would be nice. What I did was just branch off of master, git-mv the static files to the root directory, and git-rm everything else. Now I can just merge changes from master, delete the conflicting files, and push. It's a pretty crappy hack, but it gets the job done...
@acdha nope, that was totally a coincidence. I've been thinking about doing this for a while.
The thing I'd like for a gh-pages clone is something which would handle the "build sphinx docs in master, stash output, checkout gh-pages, add and commit" process
@joshourisman Ditto. readthedocs.org is great for simply projects but e.g. auto-moduling NativeImaging would require 2 C libraries and two different python runtimes to be installed…
I have a second checkout of my repo in project/docs/build/htmldir/ checked out gh_pages branch
then `fab docs` rebuilds them, does commit -A in that directory, and pushes up
@acdha: In that case, you could probably build locally as a post-commit hook and push an HTML bundle. (if that is finished..I don't remember)
https://github.com/shichuan/mobile-html5-boilerplate
I'm still in the D > Go camp.

i dislike forced gc, for example. i dont like the structural typing bit.
most of my quibbles are admittedly minor.
For me, it has to be Dos on Dope: http://secretgeek.net/dod_intro.asp
well, first of all, i've been using D since longer than Go has been alive.
my friends and i are writing an os in it.
D does have large social problems. i just ignore those.
